subject: Languages
title: Language vs. Dialect: A Political Question
description: Learn Language vs. Dialect: A Political Question in one minute.

hook.text: A famous quip says: 'A language is a dialect with an army and a navy.' It's more true than funny.

buildup.text: Linguistically, there's no clear boundary between a language and a dialect.

discovery.text: Norwegians and Swedes understand each other â€” separate languages. Mandarin and Cantonese speakers can't â€” same language.

twist.text: The distinction is political, not linguistic. National borders create 'languages.' Lack of power creates 'dialects.'

climax.text: Hindi and Urdu are nearly identical in speech. But one is written in Devanagari, the other in Arabic script.

punchline.text: Whether you speak a language or a dialect depends more on politics than on grammar.

quiz.question: What determines whether something is a 'language' or 'dialect'?
options: Political and social factors, not just linguistic ones
Whether it has a writing system
